Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: ANALYSIS SOURCE: The source that the analysis came from, this could be a labtechnician, a lab, a company, a government agency, etc.
Column Comment.2: PARAMETER OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique number that identifies theparameter for the sample analysis.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ANALYSIS VALUE REMARK: A narrative remark about the analysis of the value.
Column Comment.5: AVERAGE VALUE: The average or single value assigned to this specification. If onlyone measure is provided, it should be stored here.
Column Comment.8: CATALOGUE EQUIPMENT IDENTIFER: use this column to identify the make andmodel of the equipment used.
Column Comment.9: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.10: EQUIPMENT IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the specific piece of equipment usedin this study. If you only know the general make and model of the equipment, useCAT EQUIP ID.
Column Comment.11: EQUIPMENT OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique number which allows for multipleobservations by a piece of equipment during sample analysis.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.13: MAXIMUM DATE: Some parameter steps require a process to be conducted for aperiod of time. For example aged oil may be left exposed to the open air for someperiod of time. Use this column to indicate the start and end time for a step.
Column Comment.14: MAXIMUM VALUE: The maximum value assigned to this specification, such as thehighest or ending temperature for a process.
Column Comment.17: STANDARD METHOD SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a set or group ofstandard methods. Often, these would identify a method, consisting of severaldifferent steps, that are included in a typical analysis.
Column Comment.18: METHOD PARAMETER OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique identifier for theparameter used in this method. It is not necessary for the observation number toimply the sequence that this parameter should exist in the method, as the sequencecan vary during use of the method.
Column Comment.19: STANDARD METHOD SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a set or group ofstandard methods. Often, these would identify a method, consisting of severaldifferent steps, that are included in a typical analysis.
Column Comment.20: MINUMUM DATE: Some parameter steps require a process to be conducted for aperiod of time. For example aged oil may be left exposed to the open air for someperiod of time. Use this column to indicate the start and end time for a step.
Column Comment.21: MINUMUM VALUE: The minimum value assigned to this specification, such as thelowest, or starting temperature for a process.
Column Comment.24: PARAMETER BUSINESS ASSOCIATE: Unique identifier for the business associatewho applied this parameter to an analysis step, available in the rare case that this isneeded.
Column Comment.25: SAMPLE ANALYSIS STANDARD PARAMETER: this table lists the types ofparameters that may be applied to an analysis. Typical examples might beparameters about how much a sample is heated, the type of solvent used, how finelya sample is ground (or sliced) etc. This column may be validated both from theANL_METHOD table, which controls valid methods and their allowed parameters, orsimply through the parameter reference list. Note the controlling the value from theANL METHOD FK will be more difficult, but will provide a much higher degree ofquality support, as only parameters that are valid for the method will be permitted.
Column Comment.26: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.27: REFERENCE VALUE: The value of the reference point. For example a temperaturemay be measured at standard atmospheric pressure.
Column Comment.29: REFERENCE VALUE TYPE: In the event that a parameter is provided relative tosome other measure, use this set of columns. For example, a temperature may beachieved at standard atmospheric pressure.
Column Comment.31: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.32: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.33: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample.
Column Comment.34: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.35: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.36: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.37: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.38: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.39: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.40: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.41: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
